Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Obama warned against Covid vaccines, when there is no official evidence or public speeches supporting this claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no official evidence or public speeches to back up the statement that Obama warned against Covid vaccines.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Obama's alleged quote about being an accomplice and white people killing Africans with toxic vaccines is true, without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Obama publicly stated on his Twitter account that getting vaccinated is one of the most important things we can do.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation could be that the false Obama quote was spread to create controversy or misinformation, as it coincided with the viral broadcast of two French doctors' comments about testing vaccines in Africa.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting the alleged quote as if it were true without providing any concrete evidence or official statements from Obama.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the provided claim.
